questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with a history of mild visual disturbances in one eye. Upon examination, a small white dot is noted on the posterior lens capsule, and no other abnormalities are observed. This finding is most likely a remnant of which of the following embryological structures?
questions.solution:
1. Tunica Vasculosa Lentis:

  • Location: Surrounding the lens.
  • Origin: The vascular network (tunica vasculosa lentis) supports the developing lens.

Description: Normally regresses by the time of birth. If remnants persist, they can be observed as fine strands or pigment spots, sometimes associated with Mittendorf's dot or epicapsular stars.

A. Tunica vasculosa lentis: Correct. The tunica vasculosa lentis is a vascular network that supplies nutrients to the developing lens during embryogenesis. A small white dot on the posterior surface of the lens, known as Mittendorf's dot, is a remnant of the hyaloid artery, part of the tunica vasculosa lentis.

  • Neural crest cells: Incorrect. Neural crest cells contribute to the development of the cornea, iris, and parts of the sclera. Defects in neural crest cell migration typically lead to conditions like Axenfeld's anomaly or Peters' anomaly, which affect the anterior segment, not the lens.
  • Choroid fissure: Incorrect. The choroid fissure is involved in the development of the optic nerve and retina. Incomplete closure of this fissure leads to a coloboma, typically affecting the iris, retina, or optic nerve, but not the lens.
  • Surface ectoderm: Incorrect. The surface ectoderm forms the lens placode, which invaginates to form the lens. However, remnants of the lens development process, like Mittendorf's dot, are linked to the hyaloid artery rather than the surface ectoderm.

Clinical Relevance:

  • Persistent fetal vasculature (PFV): Significant remnants of the hyaloid system, such as a persistent hyaloid artery, can result in PHPV, leading to visual impairment, retinal detachment, or cataract formation.
  • Coloboma: A defect in the closure of the choroid fissure can result in a coloboma, typically affecting the retina, iris, or optic nerve.

#anatomy of eye #embryological remnants #should know

Reference:

Kanski, Jack J., and Bowling, Brad. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th Edition, Elsevier, 2016, Chapter 1, page number:. 1-10.

questions.text:
A newborn presents with a keyhole-shaped defect in the inferior portion of the iris in both eyes. The mother's prenatal history is unremarkable, and there were no reported complications during delivery. This congenital defect is attributed to improper closure of the choroid fissure during development.
Which of the following structures is least likely to be affected by the same developmental process?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Options:

Option D). Cornea: Correct. The cornea develops from surface ectoderm and neural crest cells, independent of the choroid fissure. Therefore, it is not affected by incomplete closure of the fissure.

Option A). Retina: Incorrect. The retina develops from the optic cup, which forms from the neural ectoderm. Incomplete closure of the choroid fissure can result in a retinal coloboma, affecting its inferior portion.

Option B). Optic nerve: Incorrect. The optic nerve forms from the optic stalk, which is continuous with the developing retina. A defect in the choroid fissure can affect the optic nerve, leading to optic nerve coloboma.

Option C). Choroid: Incorrect. The choroid develops from neural crest cells that surround the developing optic cup. Anomalies in choroid fissure closure can lead to a choroidal coloboma.

Embryological derivatives of eye

Choroid Fissure Closure and Coloboma:

  • The choroid fissure forms along the ventral aspect of the optic stalk during early eye development. It allows entry of the hyaloid artery to nourish the developing eye. Normally, the choroid fissure closes by the 7th week of gestation.
  • Incomplete closure of the choroid fissure results in a coloboma, a congenital defect that can involve the iris, retina, optic nerve, and choroid, often presenting as a keyhole-shaped defect in the affected structures.
  • The cornea is not involved in this process since it develops separately from the surface ectoderm and neural crest cells.

KEY TAKE AWAYS:

Incomplete closure of the choroid fissure results in a coloboma, a congenital defect that can involve the iris, retina, optic nerve, and choroid, often presenting as a keyhole-shaped defect in the affected structures.

#choroidal fissure closure #coloboma #fundal Coloboma #must know

Reference:

Kanski, Jack J., and Bowling, Brad. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th Edition, Elsevier, 2016, Chapter 1, page number. 1-8

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is diagnosed with a rare condition where the lens is absent bilaterally (aphakia). During embryogenesis, failure in the induction of which of the following structures most likely resulted in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Options:

Option A). Surface ectoderm: Correct. The lens develops from the surface ectoderm. The optic vesicle induces the surface ectoderm to form the lens placode, which eventually invaginates to form the lens vesicle. Failure of this induction process results in congenital aphakia, or the absence of the lens.

  • Option B). Optic vesicle: Incorrect. While the optic vesicle induces the surface ectoderm to form the lens, defects in the optic vesicle itself usually result in malformations of the optic cup, leading to abnormalities in the retina or optic nerve, rather than aphakia.
  • Option C). Neural crest cells: Incorrect. Neural crest cells contribute to structures like the corneal stroma, endothelium, and sclera, but they do not play a direct role in lens formation. A defect in neural crest cell migration would lead to abnormalities like corneal opacity or aniridia, not aphakia.
  • Option D). Optic stalk: Incorrect. The optic stalk gives rise to the optic nerve. Defects in its development can result in optic nerve hypoplasia or coloboma, but not aphakia.

KEY TAKE AWAYS:

#embryology of eye #development of lens

Reference:

Kanski, Jack J., and Bowling, Brad. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th Edition, Elsevier, 2016, Chapter 1, page number:1-8.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with blurred vision and glare, particularly at night. Upon examination, a significant cataract is noted in the lens. Which type of cataract is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Nuclear Cataract:
    • Common in older adults.
    • Causes blurred vision and glare, especially in low light.
    • Characterized by hardening and yellowing of the lens nucleus.
  • Other Options:
    • Cortical Cataract: Typically presents with radial spoke-like opacities; causes glare.
    • Posterior Subcapsular Cataract: Affects the back of the lens; may cause significant visual impairment early on.
    • Congenital Cataract: Present at birth or develops in early childhood.

#nuclear sclerosis #cataract types

Reference:

Kanski, J. J., & Bowling, B. (2015). Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach (8th Edition.). Elsevier. page number:445-447.

choices.text: The nasolacrimal duct opens into the inferior meatus of the nasal cavity, and is surrounded by the bony canal of the maxilla.
The canaliculi connect directly to the lacrimal sac without any intervening structures, allowing for immediate drainage of tears.
The puncta are located at the temporal side of the eyelids and serve as the primary site for tear absorption into the drainage system.
The common canaliculus is formed by the convergence of the superior and inferior canaliculi before draining into the lacrimal sac.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with persistent epiphora due to obstruction in the lacrimal drainage system. During surgical intervention, an anatomical study reveals the relationship between the structures involved in tear drainage. Which of the following statements regarding the anatomical connections and pathways of the lacrimal drainage system is most accurate?
questions.solution:
• Option A). The nasolacrimal duct opens into the inferior meatus of the nasal cavity, and is surrounded by the bony canal of the maxilla: Partially correct. While the nasolacrimal duct does indeed open into the inferior meatus, it is surrounded by the bony canal of the lacrimal bone rather than primarily the maxilla. This statement is misleading in its emphasis.
  • Option B). The canaliculi connect directly to the lacrimal sac without any intervening structures, allowing for immediate drainage of tears: Incorrect. The canaliculi do connect to the lacrimal sac, but they do not allow for immediate drainage as they must first transport tears from the puncta.
  • Option C). The puncta are located at the temporal side of the eyelids and serve as the primary site for tear absorption into the drainage system: Incorrect. The puncta are actually located on the nasal side (medial aspect) of the eyelids, not the temporal side.
  • Option D). The common canaliculus is formed by the convergence of the superior and inferior canaliculi before draining into the lacrimal sac: Correct. The common canaliculus is formed by the merging of the superior and inferior canaliculi, and it drains into the lacrimal sac, accurately representing the anatomy of tear drainage.

Anatomy of the Lacrimal Apparatus

  1. Lacrimal Gland:
    • Location: Superior lateral part of the orbit, nestled in the lacrimal fossa of frontal bone.
    • Size: Almond-shaped, approximately 20 mm in length.
    • Division: Divided into two parts:
      • Orbital part (larger) and palpebral part (smaller).
  2. Excretory Ducts:
    • Number: Typically 6-12 ducts.
    • Pathway: Open into the conjunctival sac, spreading tears across the eye surface.
  3. Puncta:
    • Location:
      • Superior punctum: On the upper eyelid.
      • Inferior punctum: On the lower eyelid.
  4. Canaliculi:
    • Length: Each canaliculus is about 8-10 mm long.
    • Structure:
      • Superior canaliculus: Drains tears from the superior punctum.
      • Inferior canaliculus: Drains from the inferior punctum.
  5. Lacrimal Sac:
    • Location: Medial aspect of the orbit, within the lacrimal fossa(lacrimal bone and frontal process of maxilla).
  6. Nasolacrimal Duct:
    • Length: Approximately 18-20 mm.
    • Pathway: Travels from the lacrimal sac through the bony canal in the lacrimal and maxillary bones.
    • Opening: Drains into the inferior meatus of the nasal cavity, approximately 1 cm posterior to the anterior nasal spine.
  7. Clinical Considerations:
    • Dacryocystitis: Inflammation or infection of the lacrimal sac, often due to obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct.
    • Epiphora: Excess tearing resulting from obstruction in any part of the drainage system.
    • Dry Eye Syndrome: Insufficient tear production or poor tear quality affecting ocular surface health and comfort.

#anatomy of lacrimal apparatus #lacrimal sac drainage #should know

Reference:

Kanski, Jack J., and Bowling, Brad. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th Edition, Elsevier, 2016. page number: 102-108

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with recurrent itching, redness, and watering of both eyes, worse during the summer. On examination, large cobblestone papillae are noted on the upper tarsal conjunctiva, and the cornea shows superficial punctate keratitis. What is the next best step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
• Vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) is an allergic eye disease characterized by large cobblestone papillae and seasonal exacerbation. Topical antihistamines (combined with mast cell stabilizers) are the first-line treatment to control allergic inflammation and symptoms.

Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) is a chronic allergic eye condition primarily affecting children and young adults, characterized by inflammation of the conjunctiva and cornea. It is associated with seasonal allergic reactions, particularly to grass pollen.

Key Features:

  1. Symptoms:
    • Intense itching and burning sensation in the eyes.
    • Redness and watering of the eyes.
    • Photophobia (sensitivity to light).
  2. Signs:
    • Follicular conjunctivitis: Presence of large cobblestone-like papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva.
  • Limbal infiltrates: Known as Herbert's pits, which are indicative of chronic inflammation.
  • Pannus formation: Superficial neovascularization and opacification of the cornea in advanced cases.
  1. Epidemiology:
    • More common in males and typically presents in childhood, with a peak incidence between ages 5 and 20.
    • Common in warm, dry climates, correlating with seasonal pollen exposure.

Pathophysiology:

  • VKC is an IgE-mediated hypersensitivity The release of inflammatory mediators (e.g., histamine, eosinophils) leads to conjunctival inflammation and ocular surface damage.

Management:

  1. Medical Treatment:
    • Topical antihistamines and mast cell stabilizers (e.g., olopatadine) for symptomatic relief.
    • Topical corticosteroids may be used for severe inflammation but with caution due to potential side effects.

Cold compresses and lubricants for symptom relief.

Incorrect options:

  • Topical corticosteroids: Used only in severe or refractory cases due to the risk of side effects like glaucoma and cataract.
  • Topical cyclosporine: An option for chronic or refractory cases but not first-line.
  • Cool compresses and artificial tears: Provide symptomatic relief but do not treat the underlying allergic inflammation.

#Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) #cornea #signs in VKC

Reference:
Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 9th edition. Elsevier; 2015. page number:181-184

questions.text: A 28-year-old kindergarten teacher complains of a gritty sensation and discharge from the right eye for 3 days. She also has rhinorrhea, mild sore throat, and low-grade fever of 37.9 C (100.3 F). The symptoms began a week after classes started in the fall. Her past medical history is significant for genital herpes and endometriosis. Eye examination shows mild injection and granular appearance of the tarsal conjunctiva of the right eye with profuse watery discharge. Nasal mucosa is normal, and the pharynx has mild erythema without exudates. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Conjunctivitis treatment

Bacterial conjunctivitis- Erythromycin ointment, Polymyxin-trimethoprim drops

  • Azithromycin drops- Preferred agent in contact lens wearers: fluoroquinolone drops

Viral conjunctivitis- Warm or cold compresses ± Antihistamine/decongestant drops

Allergic conjunctivitis - Over-the-counter antihistamine/decongestant drops for intermittent symptoms, Mast cell stabilizer/antihistamine drops for frequent episodes

  • This patient, with conjunctival inflammation and watery discharge in the setting of an upper respiratory illness, has typical features of viral conjunctivitis("pinkeye"). Most cases are caused by adenovirus, and outbreaks are common among small children and caregivers in late summer and early fall.
  • Symptoms typically last several days and are self-limited. Occasional cases can develop a secondary bacterial infection ("bacterial superinfection") with more severe pain and grossly purulent exudate. Purulent bacterial conjunctivitis responds to topical antibiotic therapy (Choice B), but uncomplicated viral conjunctivitis can be managed symptomatically.

(Choice C) Mast cell stabilizing agents, such as olopatadine and azelastine, are indicated for treatment of allergic conjunctivitis. Although symptoms of allergic and viral conjunctivitis are often similar, allergic conjunctivitis typically occurs episodically with a shorter duration of symptoms.

Choice C) Mast cell stabilizing agents, such as olopatadine and azelastine, are indicated for treatment of  allergic conjunctivitis. Although symptoms of allergic and viral conjunctivitis are often similar, allergic conjunctivitis typically occurs episodically with a shorter duration of symptoms. In addition, although many viral conjunctivitis symptoms may be due to release of histamine from mast cells, mast cell stabilizers have not been well studied for this purpose and are generally not needed.

(Choice D) Oral antiviral medications, such as acyclovir and valacyclovir, are recommended for treatment of-and corneal ulcers. Antiviral agents would not be effective in this patient with typical adenoviral conjunctivitis.

Key takeaways:

Viral conjunctivitis is a self-limited condition associated with adenovirus and other viral upper respiratory illnesses. It is common in sporadic outbreaks, especially among children and caregivers in late summer and early fall. No specific treatment is needed, although some patients may develop a bacterial superinfection which requires topical antibiotics.

Reference: parsons diseases of eye 24th edition, conjuctiva, page number:484

questions.text: ECONOMIC blindness according to NPCB, is?

A 34-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a red eye. He says,"I just woke up this morning and saw that my right eye was red." He denies any itching, pain or discharge. He has no known drug or environmental allergies. He takes no medication. His vital signs are stable. The photo of his eye is shown below

What is the best next step in his management?
questions.solution:
This patient has a subconjunctival hemorrhage. He woke up with a red eye, and is entirely asymptomatic. Subconjunctival hemorrhage is a completely benign condition. It may be due to simple trauma from rubbing the eyes vigorously, violent coughing spells, hypertensive episodes or coagulopathy. In the majority of cases, the condition is from minor bruising and does not require any workup at all. The hemorrhage usually disappears in 24 to 48 hours. Simple observation is the best treatment. The occasional patient with subconjunctival hemorrhage may have an elevated blood pressure. In such rare cases, lowering of the blood pressure may be useful.

(Choice A) The intraocular pressure is usually monitored in individuals with suspected glaucoma. Features of glaucoma include visual loss, pupillary dilatation and erythema around the conjunctiva. The eyeball may feel hard to palpation. A tonometer reveals the increased intraocular pressure. The treatment is a topical cholinergic or beta blocker eye drops.

(Choice B) The occasional patient who is on anticoagulation medication may develop a subconjunctival hemorrhage. Measurements of coagulation parameters may be indicated in such a case. Therapy is conservative.

(Choice D) Antibiotics are not required for subconjunctival hemorrhage because the condition is not infectious. Conjunctivitis can present with discharge and redness of the eye. Topical antibiotic drops are required.

Reference: Parsons diseases of eye 24th edition conjuctiva page number:480.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the clinic with progressive vision loss and a history of mood swings. On examination, you note a greenish-brown ring at the corneal margin. The patient also exhibits tremors and hepatic dysfunction. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
• Correct answer: The presence of a Kayser-Fleischer ring is a classic sign of Wilson's disease, a genetic disorder that leads to excessive copper accumulation in the body, affecting the liver and brain. The greenish-brown ring results from copper deposits in the corneal margin.

Kayser-Fleischer ring is a distinctive greenish-brown ring found at the corneal margin, formed by the deposition of copper in the corneal tissue. It is most commonly associated with Wilson's disease, a genetic disorder characterized by impaired copper metabolism.

Key Features:

  1. Etiology:
    • Wilson's disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, leading to impaired biliary excretion of copper and subsequent accumulation in various tissues.
  2. Associated Symptoms:
    • Neurological symptoms (e.g., tremors, dystonia).
    • Psychiatric manifestations (e.g., mood swings, personality changes).
    • Hepatic dysfunction (e.g., liver cirrhosis, acute liver failure).
  3. Diagnosis:
    • Diagnosis is confirmed by measuring serum ceruloplasmin levels, urinary copper excretion, and performing a slit-lamp examination to identify KF rings.
    • Genetic testing may also be conducted for definitive diagnosis.
  4. Management:
    • Treatment involves copper chelators to reduce copper levels.
    • Zinc supplements may also be used to inhibit copper absorption.
    • Liver transplantation may be necessary in advanced cases.

Incorrect options:

  • Hemochromatosis: Characterized by iron overload; does not cause KF rings.
  • Copper deficiency: Would not present with KF rings; rather, it may cause neurological symptoms without the corneal findings.
  • Diabetes mellitus: Typically not associated with KF rings..

#wilson's disease #KF ring

Reference:
Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th Edition. Elsevier; 2015. page number:. 546-548.

questions.text: An infant with intolerance to breast feed, vomiting and diarrhoea develops cataract. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Galactosemia - becomes manifest during infancy with features of failure to thrive, lethargy, vomiting and diarrhea. Reducing substance is found ni urine after drinking milk. Cataract develops (oil droplet central opacity) within firs: few days to weeks of life. The exclusion of galactose (milk and milk products) from the diet will prevent the progression of cataract and may reverse early lens changes.

Other options:

Option A) Lowe syndrome: x linked recessive disorder

Triad of : congenital cataract, renal failure, intellectual delay,

It is not associated with diarrhoea, intolerance to breast feeding etc

Option C) fabry's disease - x linked recessive disorder, due to enzyme deficiency of alpha galactosidase, not associated with congenital cataracts

Option D) congenital hypoglycemia: is aka congenital hyperinsulinemia - beta islet cell hyperplasia, not associated with congenital cataract.

Reference: Kanski clinical Ophthalmology, 7/edition, page number:301

The posterior capsule si usually left intact

questions.text: Pterygium causes visual disturbances due to:
questions.solution:
PTERYGIUM

  • A triangular, fibrovascular growth of degenerative subconjunctival tissue over the cornea destroying its Bowman's membrane and superficial stroma
  • Most commonly seen nasally situated always within the palpebral aperture®, though it can be present temporally-also known as double pterygium

Cause

Clinical features:

  • Islets of vogt and stockers line (iron deposition) are seen anterior to the Head of pteryguim
  • May present with Visual disturbances if it encroaches upon the visual axis (> 4 mm)
  • Corneal astigmatism - with the rule
  • Cosmetic intolerance

questions.text: A 28yr old lady who had just delivered a baby 24hrs before was very concerned after she read article on google about a baby's visual acuity not being normal at birth. You can reassure the mother, that the baby attains a normal level of visual acuity is at?
questions.solution:
• Fixation starts developing by 4-6 weeks. The critical period for the development of fixation reflex is 2-4 months. Development of fixation is completed by 6 months
  • Fixation development is completed by 6 months
  • The macula is fully developed by 4-6 months
  • Fusional reflex, stereopsis, and accomodation are well developed by 4-6 months
  • Cornea attains normal adult diameter by by 2yrs of age
  • The lens grows throughout life
  • Full visual acuity is attained by 3 yrs of age

Reference: Comprehensive ophthalmology 4th edition by A K Khurana page number-12

questions.text: 66 yrs old male who was homeless was brought to ophthalmology OPD. On examination, a dense haemorrhage in the posterior chamber of the right eye was found involving the visual axis. The normal anatomical contents of this chamber is\are?
questions.solution:
• Both anterior chamber and posterior chamber contains aqueous humor
  • Posterior chamber (PC) - space between posterior surface of iris and anterior surface of lens
  • Posterior chamber contains aqueous humor
  • Posterior segment contains vitreous humor
